Greg Walden"> I look forward to hearing from all of our witnesses. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Walden">With that, Madam Chair, I yield back the balance of my time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Walden">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. FRANK PALLONE, JR., A REPRESENTATIVEIN CONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. FRANK PALLONE"> Mr. Pallone, you're recognized for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Pallone</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Pallone">Thank you, Madam Chair.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Pallone">The internet is a powerful engine of economic growth and a potent platform for free speech. With a working broadband connection, anyone can work from home, sell their own products online, and connect with companies a world away.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Pallone">And in the past few years, we have seen how the internet can help everyday people launch a worldwide political movement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Pallone">But the power of the internet is rooted in the principles of net neutrality. These principles are simple and well understood. Broadband companies cannot pick internet winners and losers by blocking or slowing down content or charging extra for fast lanes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Pallone">It's a question of fairness, and there are no loopholes. Until the Trump administration took over the FCC, even the broadband providers themselves supported these principles, including a flat ban on fast lanes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Pallone">The largest providers told us time and again that they agreed that paid prioritization should be prohibited. They said that they had no intention of charging anyone extra for faster speeds.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Pallone">But recently those voices have gone silent, and that silence presents a real threat to small businesses and speech online. Where there was once agreement on a prohibition on fast lanes, some now want to add loopholes to net neutrality. The reasoning is convoluted and confusing. They argue that somehow allowing broadband providers to charge small companies extra for internet fast lanes is good for small business. But that makes no sense, and no one's buying it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Pallone">Small businesses oppose having to pay extra for fast lanes. So do telemedicine companies, disabled veterans groups, self- driving-car companies, churches, nonprofit, and the list goes on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Pallone">Net neutrality advocates have spoken loud and clear. We want everyone to have a faster internet, not just the chosen few who can afford to pay extra, and that's why Democrats on this committee introduced the LIFT America Act to bring faster broadband to everyone.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Pallone">The only ones who want broadband providers to charge money for fast lanes are the broadband providers, and despite these latest attempts to muddy the water and create confusion, banning paid prioritization is not a new issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Pallone">The FCC solved this problem when it passed net neutrality in 2015. At that time, the FCC correctly banned these fast lanes with the exception of certain specialized services like health care.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Pallone">The FCC got it right in 2015 and the Trump FCC got it wrong when it killed net neutrality last year, and that's why I support the legislation introduced by Ranking Member Doyle that would restore the well-crafted and balanced 2015 protections, and I encourage any of my colleagues who support real net neutrality to sign on to Ranking Member Doyle's CRA as well.</paragraph>

<opening>Prepared statement of Hon. Frank Pallone, Jr.</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">The CRA is the best way to put net neutrality back in place and support small businesses, and I'd like to yield the remaining time to Ms. Eshoo.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">The internet is a powerful engine of economic growth and a potent platform for free speech. With a working broadband connection, anyone can work from home, sell their own products online, and connect with companies a world away. And in the past few years, we have seen how the internet can help everyday people launch a worldwide political movement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">But the power of the internet is rooted in the principles of net neutrality. These principles are simple and well understood: broadband companies cannot pick internet winners and losers by blocking, or slowing down content or charging extra for fast lanes. It's a question of fairness, and there are no loopholes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">Until the Trump administration took over the FCC, even the broadband providers themselves supported these principles, including a flat ban on fast lanes. The largest providers told us time and again that they agreed that paid prioritization should be prohibited. They said that they had no intention of charging anyone extra for faster speeds. But recently, those voices have gone silent, and that silence presents a real threat to small businesses and speech online.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">Where there was once agreement on a prohibition on fast lanes, some now want to add loopholes to net neutrality. The reasoning is convoluted and confusing-they argue that somehow allowing broadband providers to charge small companies extra for internet fast lanes is good for small business.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">This makes no sense and no one is buying it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">Small businesses oppose having to pay extra for fast lanes. So do telemedicine companies, disabled veterans groups, self- driving car companies, churches, non-profits, and the list goes on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">Net neutrality advocates have spoken loud and clear: we want everyone to have a faster internet, not just the chosen few who can afford to pay extra. That's why Democrats on this committee introduced the LIFT America Act to bring faster broadband to everyone.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">The only ones who want broadband providers to charge more for fast lanes are the broadband providers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">Despite these latest attempts to muddy the water and create confusion, banning paid prioritization is not a new issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">The FCC solved this problem when it passed net neutrality in 2015. At that time, the FCC correctly banned these fast lanes, with the exception of certain specialized services like healthcare. The FCC got it right in 2015 and the Trump FCC got it wrong when it killed net neutrality last year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone">That's why I support the legislation introduced by Ranking Member Doyle that would restore the well-crafted and balanced 2015 protections. And I encourage any of my colleagues who support real net neutrality to sign on to Ranking Member Doyle's CRA as well. This CRA is the best way to put net neutrality back in place and support small businesses.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone"> Thank you. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Eshoo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">I thank our ranking member, and good morning, everyone. And to the witnesses: Welcome, and thank you for being here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">We are now a decade into the fight to protect net neutrality, and throughout that time there have been many arguments from those who oppose it: that it will kill jobs, it would harm investment, or hurt the free press.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">All of these have been refuted each in turn. This is actually, I think, a very simple issue. It's about fairness and equal access to an essential resource, the internet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">The 2015 Open Internet Order created the strongest, most reliable rules to protect that level playing field for innovation. The courts and the FCC both acknowledged that net neutrality was critical to the virtuous cycle that has enabled the internet to act as a tool of growth, of innovation, of investment, and of free expression.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">That same FCC found that paid prioritization is inherently harmful to that fruitful cycle that fuels education, jobs, and our economy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">Yet now we have the same companies who proclaim in full- page newspaper ads that they support net neutrality, but they are pushing for an exception for prioritization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">This is about money. This is about money. We should just all acknowledge that and have a debate about it. But it's all about money.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">We may be a decade down the road, but it's about the same thing that it always has been about, and that is who controls the onramps to the internet, being able to pick winners or losers, and that's based on pay to play. It is about money.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">I don't blame companies for wanting to make money. That's what they are in the business to do. But we have an obligation to the public, and I think that's what this debate is about.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">So I look forward to hearing from the witnesses, and I think everyone knows exactly where I stand on this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Ms. Eshoo"> [Laughter.] </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Eshoo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">I yield back. Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentlelady yields back. Mr. Pallone yields back, and this concludes our Member opening statements.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">I will remind the committee that each Member's opening statement will be made a part of the permanent record for the committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Ms. Eshoo">We thank our witnesses for being here today, and you all are going to have the opportunity to give your opening statements, followed by a round of questions from our Members.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Ms. Eshoo"> Our panel today: Mr. Richard Bennett, founder of High Tech Forum; Mr. Peter ``Ree-sa-vay''--am I saying that properly? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">``Ri-sah-vy.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Mrs. Blackburn. Rysavy, president of Rysavy Research; Mr. Paul Schroeder, director of public policy and strategic alliances at Aira Tech Corporation; and Matt Wood, policy director at Free Press.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">We appreciate each of you for being here today and for providing your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Mr. Bennett, we begin with you. Please, each one of you as you speak, turn your microphones on. And, Mr. Bennett, you are recognized for 5 minutes for an opening statement. STATEMENTS OF RICHARD BENNETT, FOUNDER, HIGH TECH FORUM; PETER</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF RICHARD BENNETT</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="RICHARD BENNETT"> RYSAVY, PRESIDENT, RYSAVY RESEARCH; PAUL W. SCHROEDER, DIRECTOR, PUBLIC POLICY AND STRATEGIC ALLIANCES, AIRA TECH CORPORATION; MATTHEW F. WOOD, POLICY DIRECTOR, FREE PRESS AND </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Bennett</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Bennett">Good morning, Chairman Blackburn, and hello to Chairman Walden, Ranking Member Doyle, and Ranking Member Pallone, and members of the committee, especially Ms. Eshoo, whose district I used to live in and who gave me a really hard time the first time I testified before this committee, but I probably deserved it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Bennett">Prioritization has been part of the internet's design from the beginning in that there is a type of service field in the internet protocol header, and it's been refined through integrated services, a standard design in the 1990s, then differentiated services, so there is not by itself anything controversial about prioritization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Bennett">And I think it's fair to say that, while it was controversial for a time, it's come to be recognized there is a consensus sort of support that, done correctly, prioritization is beneficial to applications.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So we have reached this consensus, I think, after about 15 years of debate around what we call net neutrality now, that it's legitimate for ISPs, CDNs, transit networks, and purpose- built networks like WebEx to accelerate time-sensitive traffic.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Bennett">If you go back to the original paper that Chairman Wheeler wrote on net neutrality, he points out that the internet is inherently biased against real-time applications as a class and biased in favor of content applications, and I think if we are not careful about how we treat paid prioritization we can make that bias worse, and that's something we should try to avoid.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Bennett">I think we also--going back to the consensus question--we also believe that competition is a good thing. We want tech policies that increase that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So prioritization and the related technologies such as resource reservation, traffic shaping, and dynamic path selection have not only become commonplace, but I think they are widely regarded as essential to certainly the real-time applications part of the internet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Bennett">And this is good, because no matter how much capacity networks have, we can also always make their operation more efficient if we apply optimization techniques. There are certain problems that we solve without optimization that you can't really build your way out of simply by throwing more capacity at the problem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Bennett">It's like trying to solve, you know, throwing money at problems that you don't really understand.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Bennett">And I think we appreciate that prioritization mechanisms such as the IEEE 802.11(e) standard that I helped design are beneficial to real-time applications such as voice in the same way that LTE bearers are.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Bennett">The fact that one is provided free on a closed enterprise network and the other is sold as part of a bundle that includes carrier grade voice I think doesn't really impact on their utility. These are useful things. We found that, by prioritizing voice and Wi-Fi, we get four times as many voice calls through a Wi-Fi network.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Bennett">But it's hard to explain the continual increases in broadband speed we have seen in the U.S. over the last 10 years--speed improves 35 percent per year--without giving some credit to the expectation of profit.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Bennett">The fact that web speeds have stagnated over this same period, even declining in 2016, suggests something is wrong with the web's financial model, and I think you, the committee, explored that last week.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Bennett">But leaving the consumer broadband market questions aside, paid prioritization internet optimization is very important to enterprises that have to connect, say, branch offices to headquarters.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Bennett">The traditional way to do that was to lease--and in some cases still is widely done--people lease business data services lines like a T1 for $300 a month, and it only gives you 1.5 megabits per second.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Bennett">But with prioritization, you could actually--with the proper management, you could actually use a public common internet connection to connect the branch office to the headquarters.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Bennett">And so now you're getting 50 to 250 megabits per second for less than $100 a month. But this only works--you can only have that cost savings if someone is prioritizing the traffic on that pipe.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So let's bear in mind that, while there are fees for these things, the alternatives can also be quite costly.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So it's important, I think, to recognize the internet is no longer just a research network. The internet is the network. It has replaced all the other--I mean, not quite completely, but in the next few years, all the other networks are going to be subsumed by the internet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So we can't apply the sort of, oh, like, research network standards to the internet. We have to recognize that the fundamental requirement is that it serves all the needs of all the used cases of all the people who connect to it.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Bennett follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Bennett ">And I think whatever it takes to do that is fine, you know, given the proper oversight.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Bennett ">[GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF PETER RYSAVY</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="PETER RYSAVY"> Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Chairman Blackburn, Ranking Member Doyle, and other distinguished members of the subcommittee, thank you for the opportunity to testify at this important hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">I am president of Rysavy Research, an analyst in the wireless industry with more than 25 years of experience. When I started, the hot new wireless technology was 1G.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">I am an expert in wireless technology. I've worked with many dozens of firms and have published more than 175 reports and articles. My testimony is on 5G.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">5G will start to be deployed as early as this year--end of this year--and will become the dominant wireless technology through the 2020s. It is being designed and developed by organizations, individuals from all over the world, and will employ sophisticated mechanisms to handle different kinds of traffic flows.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">This is critical because 5G is being designed to address a much wider range of use cases than prior generations of technology.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Many of the applications envisioned for 5G are of a control nature, and that means they need minimal delay and high reliability.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">These types of applications, whether it's controlling drones in real time or robots or sending emergency messages to autonomous vehicles, will depend on traffic prioritization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">5G's reliance on traffic prioritization should not be viewed as problematic for internet traffic that will not be prioritized. Traffic differentiation and prioritization is not a zero sum game.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">You can prioritize certain traffic flows without adversely affecting other users' applications. The goal in managing network traffic is to maximize the quality of experience across the entire subscriber base.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">5G needs QoS management not only for traffic prioritization to support mission critical applications but also enable a fundamental architectural component called network slicing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Again, 5G is being designed and developed for cellular operators to deploy on a global basis. Network slicing, implemented through virtualization, will allow an operator to provide different services with different performance characteristics customized for the specific use cases involved, such as those needing low latency enhanced reliability.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Even with new spectrum and expected peak throughputs that will exceed a gigabit per second, 5G networks will still have to manage latency, reliability, massive numbers of connections, and a mix of stationary and mobile users.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Capacity alone is not the solution. The United States has assumed global leadership in 4G. It enjoys deep LTE 4G penetration, leading smartphone platforms and the vibrant application ecosystem. But globally, countries and companies are investing in and concentrating on what will come next with 5G.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Constraining 5G with rules that restrict traffic management necessary for the traffic flows anticipated with 5G applications could threaten U.S. leadership in mobile technology and deployment.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Rysavy follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Rysavy ">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Rysavy ">[GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rysavy ">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF PAUL W. SCHROEDER</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="PAUL W. SCHROEDER"> Mr. Schroeder, you are recognized for 5 minutes, and I will give you a warning at 30 seconds. How's that? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Schroeder</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Thank you very much. Good morning. I think the microphone is on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Thank you, Chairman Blackburn, members of the subcommittee. Very pleased to be with you this morning. My name is Paul Schroeder, and I am here on behalf of Aira, a San Diego-based technology company.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Our groundbreaking service provides instant access to visual information for people who are blind or visually impaired. As such, our service relies on the transmission of streaming video from the network edge through mobile up to the internet without interruption at high speeds to ensure ultra- low latency connection between the blind individual and the remotely located sighted assistant who is providing information based on the video feed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">We leverage mobile communications as well as innovative technologies such as the smart glasses that I am wearing, and yes, there is a camera in the middle of these glasses that is connected to an agent as we speak. We also use GPS and other sensors, augmented reality, and are incorporating machine learning.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Besides the technology, Aira's success really depends on our human agents. They are highly trained, they are paid, they are held to a confidentiality requirement, and they do undergo background checks before they serve as an agent.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Our customers--we call them explorers--pay for access to a fixed number of minutes per month. We are, though, working with agencies such as the Department of Veterans Affairs to ensure that blind veterans have access to this critical service.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">I also want to note that Congressman Peters and Congressman Rutherford have been very helpful in leading a bipartisan effort to ensure that the VA is paying attention to these new technologies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">This week, Aira has designated the congressional office buildings as free Aira zones. This was a choice we made because there is a large group of individuals who are blind visiting this week, and we know that this will help them navigate the halls of Congress more effectively.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">We encourage others to do this, and I do want to note for Chairman Blackburn, your home State airport of Memphis was the first one to join the Aira Airport Network, paying for the minutes of Aira users at Memphis airport in order to get around the airports more effectively.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Yesterday, two of our Aira explorers ran the Boston Marathon using Aira. Now, most of us, blind or sighted, probably aren't going to run a marathon. But the test of a low- latency available network was put to the test at the marathon, and many of us will have opportunities to test that in other environments, for example, hustling through an airport trying to find the gate for our airplane, checking out bus signs in a crowded bus garage to figure out the one that we need, quickly looking at a chart or slide in a meeting or a classroom, or maybe a congressional hearing, in order to get the information from that slide as a person who's blind, putting information into these kiosks that are popping up everywhere in order to order or confirm a reservation, and, of course, reading a medication label to ensure that we are actually taking the right medication.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">For those of us who are blind or visually impaired using Aira, we need instant access to this information. We need a network that is reliable and a network that has low latency, because our video is able to stream upward from the mobile edge.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">We are particularly pleased to note our partner AT&T has offered dynamic traffic management to Aira to ensure that our users have the low-latency network and reliable connectivity that they need and our agents need as well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">I am pleased to say this morning I am joined by an agent-- Amy, are you there?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Schroeder"> Agent. I am. Good morning, Paul. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Schroeder</speaker> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Oh, I left the speaker by the phone. Do you want to do a very quick description of the room, please?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Agent. Absolutely. I see three rows of a desk and that have white wood on the bottom of them and then a darker mahogany on the top of the desk and they are separated by an aisle in the middle, and the very back of the room has a single panel of speakers. I see the chairwoman is in the very middle of the room. A gentleman to her left is waving at me.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">[Laughter.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Agent. American flags that are flanking the center----</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Mrs. Blackburn. Thirty seconds.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Schroeder"> Agent [continuing]. Three windows directly across---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Schroeder</speaker> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">I am going to have you hold up, and we'll come back to you if there's a question for the agent.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">We are investing in artificial intelligence as well so that we can bring automation to our service, and we are, of course, looking forward to the emergence of 5G, which will help our low-latency network and service be even stronger.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Schroeder">Finally, I just want to say we encourage policymakers to support policies and programs that will promote and expand reliable access to visual information such as what Aira is providing as a right to those of us who are blind or visually impaired.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Schroeder follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Schroeder ">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Schroeder ">[GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Schroeder ">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF MATTHEW F. WOOD</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="MATTHEW F. WOOD"> Mr. Wood, 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Wood">Chairman Blackburn and Ranking Member Doyle, and members of the subcommittee, thank you for having me here today to testify.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Wood">Free Press is a nonpartisan nonprofit with 1.4 million members, and we were founded 15 years ago to elevate people's voices in policy decisions that shape our media.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Wood">Today, we believe that achieving racial justice and social justice require equitable access to technology and information. That's why we work on net neutrality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Wood">We supported the strong rules recently and wrongly repealed by the FCC, and we support Congressman Doyle's resolution to restore them, and we are not alone.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Wood">Hundreds of members have cosponsored that resolution in the House and Senate. Thousands of businesses and organizations and State and local officials support it, too.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Wood">Millions of people have made their voices heard, first at the FCC and then in these halls, opposing that repeal and calling on you to pass the CRA.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Wood">That's not surprising, because, as Mr. Doyle noted, poll after poll shows the net neutrality rules enjoy tremendous popular support across party lines.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Wood">One poll last summer showed that 72 percent of Republicans supported the 2015 rules. Another taken before the FCC's December vote found that 83 percent of all respondents oppose that repeal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Wood">Free Press supports restoring the entire 2015 order because we need more than three bright lines to preserve the open internet. We need FCC authority to prevent new forms of discrimination and also to address digital divides, protect privacy, and promote competition.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Wood">Yet some people claim that paid prioritization bans are harmful and they say that ISPs should be able to charge new kinds of fees and that internet users and businesses would benefit from such new charges.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Wood">They also say this would help with last-mile congestion without explaining its scope or accounting for the ways the networks already deal with that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Wood">As a general matter, prioritizing rather than building capacity to solve any last-mile congestion over a sustained period would let ISPs profit from artificial scarcity.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Wood">It would let them charge more to get through the bottleneck rather than building a bigger path. So paid prioritization is not just a solution in search of a problem, it's a toll booth in search of a traffic jam.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Wood">ISPs' own data shows that under Title II, both broadband investment and deployment speeds increased markedly in rural and urban areas alike.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Wood">Despite that evidence, some still insist that strong rules made ISPs invest too little. Now, funnily enough, we are told that the rules may make ISPs invest too much by requiring them to build both excess capacity instead of prioritizing their way out of congestion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Wood">Whatever the investment incentives of the paid prioritization ban, discarding this rule would cause a radical change to the internet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Wood">That ban prohibited ISPs favoring traffic only in exchange for payment from a third party or to benefit an ISP's affiliates such as video or voice offers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Wood">In other words, it did not ban the kinds of user-directed and application-driven traffic management techniques praised by others here today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Wood">Those kinds of practices leave ISPs' customers in control when it comes to choosing how to use those connections, and those customers already can and do choose to buy faster speed tiers when they so desire.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Wood">They could even buy what's called a quality of service tier to use on applications of their choosing and at times of their own choosing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Wood">Longstanding network protocols also can and do make these kinds of choices neutrally. ISPs don't need to inspect our internet traffic as they transmit it or to second guess how to treat it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Wood">The paid priority rule banned none of these network management techniques. It applied only if the ISP tried to make a content provider pay extra just to reach broadband customers or just to cut in line ahead of other traffic.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Wood">People already pay for their connections. The websites and apps they visit should not suddenly be asked to do so too. So if I visit marshablackburn.com or mikedoyleforcongress.com on my home connection, those websites don't have to pay my ISP to reach me.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Wood">Let me be clear. I am not here to defend big edge providers from such payments. I represent internet users. But letting gatekeeper ISPs impose new tolls would distort the choices users have and ISPs undoubtedly would get together with those largest edge providers to set the terms and prices for any such advantages.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Wood">It would be inefficient for every edge provider to have to strike such deals with every ISP in the country, and signing up for such deals means they'd be double charged for data that ISP subscribers already paid to receive.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Wood">Academics can speculate that in a different kind of access market such new fees might reduce subscriber costs. They still do not explain why ISPs facing so little competition would have any incentive to lower their retail prices.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Wood">So when ISP executives talk about paid prioritization, they don't describe it as a way to reduce revenues or to replace the source for those revenues. They talk about it as a chance to increase their revenues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Wood">That's why the notion that new ISP fees might benefit internet users and reduce their prices brings to mind a joke I've heard on several occasions. But with all due respect to the originator of that joke, I think that the most terrifying words in the language may be, ``I am from the cable company. I am here to save you money.''</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Wood follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Wood ">Thank you very much, and I look forward to your questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Wood ">[GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Wood ">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Wood ">This concludes the testimony from our witnesses. We thank you for that, and we will now move to our questions and answers. I will begin and recognize myself for 5 minutes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Wood ">Mr. Bennett, I want to come to you first. I want to discuss a tweet from Matthew Prince, the CEO of CloudFlare, from last November.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Wood ">This exchange occurred on the day the FCC made its Restoring Internet Freedom order available to the public. Someone tweeted a wish that a tech billionaire would buy out the local ISP where Chairman Pai lives and throttle his internet access in retaliation for reversing the previous Commission's order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Wood ">Matthew Prince tweeted in reply, ``I could do this in a different but equally effective way.'' He went on to say he had sent a note to his general counsel to see if CloudFlare could throttle Pai's access without breaking any laws.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Wood "> This tweet certainly raises a number of questions, and in fact it gave us the idea for this hearing. Was Matthew Prince right, and if so, how could he have done this? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Bennett</speaker> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Bennett">Thank you for the question, Chairman Blackburn.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Bennett">I remember that exchange. I got involved in it myself, actually. And I think what it illustrates is how the construction of the internet, the structure of the architecture, has changed since the sort of founding days of even really since Tim Wu came up with the idea for net neutrality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So instead of it being a system that consists of users attached, you know, with their computers and mobile devices to an infrastructure that's provided only by internet service providers, the infrastructure is actually--there's a lot going on in the infrastructure today that didn't used to be there in the very beginning, and content delivery networks have been mentioned several times, and that's one example. Technically, content delivery networks are edge services, but it turns out that all parts of the edge are not equal. So if you put a content delivery network on a portion of the edge close to the end user, then you, by that very act of simply locating the data there, you have moved the data to the head of a line that other suppliers of information that could be, say, on an average of half a nation away would have to join at the back-- you know, CDNs put you at the front.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Bennett">So CloudFlare has a number of--they're actually quite innovative products the company has. So it's sort of a--it's hard to--I am not completely a fan, but some of the things they're doing I think are very beneficial.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Bennett">I think their primary product is the DDoS protection mechanism so that, you know, sites can be subject to denial-of- service attacks if they are on the wrong side of popular opinion on certain topics, and CloudFlare came up with a way to protect sites that are being hammered with denial-of-service attacks by simply putting a really high bandwidth kind of firewall in front of the site that could absorb the denial-of- service attack and allow the website to continue to function.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Bennett">Of course, that doesn't always work the way it's planned. I used to be a visiting fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, and we published a blog called Tech Policy Daily, and we used CloudFlare's free service to protect the blog from denial-of-service attacks. AEI's the kind of organization that's sort of a target for a lot of that sort of antisocial behavior.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Bennett">But I ran into a situation once where I was unable to access a post that I would written for the blog from my home in Colorado due to a misconfiguration of the CloudFlare.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Bennett">The CloudFlare had changed some IP addresses. They hadn't told the people at AEI, and so the AEI server, which was not actually owned or controlled by CloudFlare--it was just behind the CloudFlare firewall--was unreachable to me. But people in DC could see it just fine. So it's, like, they were saying, ``Why is this a problem?''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Bennett"> Mrs. Blackburn. Let me interject and ask you one more question on this. You talked about the CDNs, and as we look at an individual user's access to certain content, who else within this ecosystem would have the opportunity to control that access or to control the speed of the individual's access? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Bennett</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Bennett">Well, the CDNs dump so much traffic on the internet I think, as it's covered in the background memo for the hearing, that they're actually in a position to affect the rate at which non-CDN users can get their jobs done.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Bennett"> Mrs. Blackburn. OK. My time has expired. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> A number of witnesses mentioned that 5G will precipitate the need for greater prioritization. If we dramatically increase the capacity of the network service, do we also need to dramatically increase our ability to manage the scarcity of it? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Wood"> I think not. Congestion doesn't solve every problem, I heard other witnesses say, but it can solve a lot of them, and as I noted in my testimony, certain kinds of prioritization actually do happen already. The question really is who's being made to pay for that. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Doyle">You know, a number of witnesses also said in their testimony, they talked about the benefits of ISPs prioritizing certain kinds of traffic over others--for instance, live video, telemedicine, and online games.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Doyle">But what happens when you take the choice away from consumers of which packets get to them first and ISPs are allowed to decide which applications and application providers will have optimized access to consumers and which ones won't?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> I mean, to me it seems like the ISPs get to pick who wins and who loses. What do you think? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Wood">Thank you, Congressman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Wood">Yes, we agree. We think retaining that user choice and the rights that users have is very important. And so you're right that certain kinds of traffic might have different network needs at different times.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Wood"> It should really be up to the user to choose not only which kinds of traffic they might wish to pay for or prioritize but also the source of that traffic. So will all video applications be treated the same way? That's a very tough question to answer when we are leaving that all within the ISPs' control. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Doyle">You know, let's talk a little bit about competition. If ISPs were allowed to implement paid prioritization for services such as telemedicine or other services, do you think that would increase or decrease the number of competitive offerings in that space?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Essentially, do you think small, rural health practices or small startups would want to compete against large health systems and the ISPs themselves or other large institutional players? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Wood">Yes, Congressman. Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Wood">I think it would decrease the amount of competitors further upstream, if you will. There's some notion that paid priority could be used to level the playing field, I suppose, and let the small businesses compete with the large businesses.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Wood">I can't see how that would work. I think that, if there were paid prioritization allowed, then naturally the companies with the deepest pockets and the providers with the biggest bank accounts would pay for that prioritization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Wood"> It wouldn't be used to level the playing field. It would just be used to tilt it even further. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Doyle">You know, a number of witnesses here today have alleged that the Open Internet Order severely restricted the types of network management an ISP could engage in.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Doyle">They also alleged that certain types of specialized service offerings such as telemedicine work prohibit it. Further, they claim that prioritization is necessary to ensure the quality of certain services, services, it seems to me, that might be best served using business data services, which I see are claimed to be too expensive.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> What do you make of that? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Wood">Well, there's a lot there. I do think that the Open Internet Order of 2015 did allow for reasonable network management. It was the term of art used for several of the rules. So even for blocking or for throttling, there were network management exceptions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Wood">For a prioritization, there was no such exception, but, of course, as I noted this morning, the ban only applied to third- party payments or prioritization done to benefit an affiliate of the internet service provider.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Wood">So all kinds of applications could receive network management. You mentioned specialized services and other kinds of dedicated capacity. Those were fully allowed by the 2015 order, and, again, even when there is a use case for prioritization on the open internet without going to a specialized service or dedicated capacity, there are protocols and methods for doing that today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Wood"> They just simply don't require the edge provider to pay on top of what the broadband user is already paying for their service. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Right.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Mr. Wood, the ban on paid prioritization, or pay to play, that was a fundamental part of net neutrality, and throughout the proceeding to eliminate neutrality protections, Chairman Pai repeatedly said that the 2015 net neutrality order was a departure from the past.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Yet, as far back as the 1970s the Commission had identified the potential harmful effects that could result when just a handful of gatekeepers could control consumers' access to the internet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Has the internet always been open and free? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Wood">We certainly think so. In the old days, you might call it, broadband providers were Title II providers. Your dial-up service worked over a phone line, and that phone company was subject to nondiscrimination rules.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Wood"> So, although the legal ground for net neutrality has shifted somewhat over the last decade as different administrations have tried to do it in different ways, the protections have always been there, and we think the 2015 version did the best job of restoring the protections we've always had. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> So why were guardrails needed when the FCC opened its proceeding that resulted in the recently overturned net neutrality protection? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Wood"> I am sorry. You said why were guardrails needed? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Yes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Wood"> I am not sure I completely understand the question. But we do think that keeping the protections we've always had was the right move. I am not sure what guardrails you're referring to in the new proceeding. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> No, in the recently overturned proceeding. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Yes. Well, I mean, again, these are fundamental rights that we think deserve protection and always have had it in some form or another, and so that's why we are looking to restore it now. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Doyle">I see my time has expired.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Thank you, Madam Chair.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Mrs. Blackburn. Gentleman yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Mr. Shimkus, you're recognized for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Thank you, Madam Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Great hearing, interesting issue, contentious views. I want to start with Mr. Schroeder, and I want to, one, thank you for being here, and secondly, I was watching your hands. Were you reading Braille or how was--how did you read to us your testimony? What was going on down there? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Schroeder</speaker> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Schroeder"> Yes, I was. I am reading off of a small Braille device. It's essentially a Braille computer that has my summarized testimony. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Great. And where is the lady who's assisting you through your glasses and the video? Where is actually she physically located? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Schroeder</speaker> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Mr. Schroeder"> Amy is in San Diego currently. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Great. Great. The gentlelady yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="186" speaker="Ms. Clarke"> Mr. Guthrie, 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Guthrie</speaker> <paragraph paraId="187" speaker="Mr. Guthrie">Thank you very much, Madam Chairwoman, and appreciate the hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="188" speaker="Mr. Guthrie">And this question is for Mr. Bennett, probably continuing on some of the same theme. Logan Telephone and Telegraph is the ISP for the last mile for a lot of the areas there that wouldn't have that kind of bargaining power that you're talking about.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="199" speaker="Mr. Guthrie">In your testimony also, you say sharing is inherent in the internet's design and go on to say access to shared resources of any kind implies the development and implementation of the sharing policy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="200" speaker="Mr. Guthrie"> Can you elaborate on what options network operators have to manage shared access to a scarce resource? Do I treat it just like generic traffic''--you know, which is probably 95 percent or it could be as much as 95 percent of the internet--``or do I give it some sort of specialized treatment?'' Let's allow some experiments like Aira to take place and examine the marketplace and then, if something is going on, then step in and correct, but preemptively allow people to innovate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="499" speaker="Mr. Bennett">Mrs. Walters. The gentlelady yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="501" speaker="Mr. Bennett"> Mr. Costello for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="502" speaker="Mr. Costello">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="503" speaker="Mr. Costello"> Mr. Rysavy, I enjoyed reading your testimony---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="504" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="505" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Mr. Costello [continuing]. And found it very helpful. I want to cite something and ask you this question. Mission critical use-case-model-type analysis that you provided, you state, ``This category of 5G application will depend on the ability to deploy traffic prioritization.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="506" speaker="Mr. Rysavy"> Can you just briefly explain why prioritization will be necessary for 5G? Is it necessary, and if so, why? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="507" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Thank you for the question, Congressman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="508" speaker="Mr. Rysavy"> Yes, prioritization is an absolutely essential aspect of 5G in enabling new use cases. The whole motivation for investing hundreds of billions of dollars in 5G networks is to expand what can be done with wireless technologies, and being able to support mission critical applications is going to be a great expansion of capabilities compared to 4G. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="509" speaker="Mr. Costello">And along that line, and I think the terminology here--I think everybody supports net neutrality, broadly speaking--certain types of paid prioritization, I think, obviously do fall under FTC and are anticompetitive.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="510" speaker="Mr. Costello"> When you speak about prioritization here, what you're speaking about is organizing slices based on the type of data and what it's used for. Is that correct? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="511" speaker="Mr. Rysavy"> That is correct. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="512" speaker="Mr. Costello"> Is there a better way for you to--would you embellish on that, if need be, or was that---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="513" speaker="Mr. Rysavy"> No, the whole point is to recognize that different types of applications have different requirements. Some may need very high bandwidth but can drop a lot of packets because it won't impact the user experience. Others might be very low bandwidth, but the reliability of information carried might be absolutely crucial. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="514" speaker="Mr. Costello"> You go on to say, ``But unprioritized and competing with other traffic, the latency ... can be 10 times higher, for example,'' and then you go on. And what you're saying there, I believe, is that, if we don't have prioritization, that you will end up across the board generalized with slower data getting from point A to point B. Is that correct? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rysavy</speaker> <paragraph paraId="515" speaker="Mr. Rysavy">Yes. The point I am making is that, if you have to treat every packet equally, that you will end up degrading the average quality of experience across the base of applications.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="516" speaker="Mr. Rysavy"> Essentially, prioritization is an extremely powerful tool for network management, and to ban it really undermines the value of these networks, moving into the future. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="517" speaker="Mr. Costello"> Mr. Wood, what's your response to that? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="518" speaker="Mr. Wood"> I think it's just where we began, Congressman: that we haven't called for a ban on prioritization done in a neutral fashion to make sure that applications work. We've called for a ban and the rules had a ban on paid prioritization, meaning that the edge provider, the app maker, whomever we want to think---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="519" speaker="Mr. Costello"> The one you have the content associated with it. But don't you agree that the FTC already has jurisdiction over that and is able to enforce? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="520" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Well, the FTC might have jurisdiction, or DOJ might if we could make it come to---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="521" speaker="Mr. Costello"> Well, they do or they don't, don't they? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="522" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Well, they have jurisdiction over certain kinds of anticompetitive conduct. They don't have jurisdiction if my own home connection is suffering because I can't reach the content that I want, and I am focused on the internet user, not just this battle between Comcast and Netflix or any other two large providers. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="523" speaker="Mr. Costello"> Isn't in the interest of the company to make sure that the user does have access? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="524" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Well, I think what we are talking about today, though, shows that there are use cases for prioritization. So they have general interest in making sure that content is available, but that they might then pick and choose which content is available at which terms for people who pay more. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="525" speaker="Mr. Costello"> I had another question. This is tangential, I apologize. But the fake comments--what is your--I mean, what is a fake comment? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="526" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Well, I think there are different kinds one could describe as less valuable. We certainly think the petition---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="527" speaker="Mr. Costello"> But isn't the FCC able to sift through that and determine what's valuable and what isn't? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="528" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Well, I think they said they are not going to decide what is fake and what isn't. So, to me, something that is obviously fake or fraudulent is somebody using---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="529" speaker="Mr. Costello"> But what's fake? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="530" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Somebody using somebody's else identification and name and address to put a comment in. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="531" speaker="Mr. Costello"> But the content, isn't it about the content and not who says it? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="532" speaker="Mr. Wood"> Well, I do think people have a right to not have things said in their name. So, if somebody put a comment in for you supporting Title II, you might care. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="533" speaker="Mr. Costello"> People say that I--fair point. But ultimately, though, the FCC would be looking at the content of the comment, not who said it. Wouldn't that be accurate? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="534" speaker="Mr. Wood"> I would hope they would look at the content, but I think it matters who said it too because people have a right to speak in their own name and not have others speak for them or pretend to speak for them. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="535" speaker="Mr. Costello"> But the FCC wouldn't decide something one way or the other just because a specific person said it or didn't say it. Wouldn't that be correct? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wood</speaker> <paragraph paraId="536" speaker="Mr. Wood"> That's right, and I think that they still have an obligation to make sure their record isn't tainted by people basically engaging in identity theft in order to make comments that are not actually their own. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Costello</speaker> <paragraph paraId="537" speaker="Mr. Costello">Sometimes we probably wish people wouldn't taint our comments too.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="538" speaker="Mr. Costello">OK. Thank you. I yield back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="539" speaker="Mr. Costello">Mrs. Blackburn. The gentleman yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="540" speaker="Mr. Costello"> Seeing that there are no further Members---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="541" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Madam Chair?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="542" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> Mrs. Blackburn. Yes, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="543" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Can I ask unanimous consent, in addition to the letters from pediatricians, telehealth experts, small businesses, and others supporting a ban of paid prioritization, I have one additional letter from the Consumers Union that I would like to introduce onto the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="544" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Mrs. Blackburn. Without objection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="545" speaker="Mr. Doyle"> [The information appears at the conclusion of the hearing.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Doyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="546" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="547" speaker="Mr. Doyle">Mrs. Blackburn.
